events.event_description: US became the world's largest LNG exporter with exports averaging 11.9 Bcf/d, a 12% increase from 2022.
events.citation: The United States exported more liquefied natural gas (LNG) than any other country in 2023. U.S. LNG exports averaged 11.9 billion cubic feet per day (Bcf/d)—a 12% increase (1.3 Bcf/d) compared with 2022

events.event_description: Freeport LNG facility returned to service and ramped up to full production.
events.citation: U.S. LNG exports increased in the first half of 2023 after Freeport LNG returned to service in February and ramped up to full production by April.

events.event_description: US LNG exports reached record levels of 13.6 Bcf/d in December 2023.
events.citation: U.S. LNG exports set monthly records late last year: 12.9 Bcf/d in November, followed by 13.6 Bcf/d in December.

events.event_description: Germany began importing LNG with the commissioning of three new FSRUs.
events.citation: Germany began importing LNG in 2023 when three new FSRUs were commissioned.

events.event_description: The Netherlands expanded Gate LNG terminal and commissioned two new FSRUs to increase import capacity.
events.citation: LNG imports increased in the Netherlands after the Gate LNG regasification terminal was expanded and two new floating storage and regasification units (FSRUs) were commissioned.

events.event_description: The Philippines and Vietnam entered the LNG import market, with Philippines specifically importing US LNG in October and November.
events.citation: The Philippines and Vietnam started importing LNG in 2023; the Philippines imported LNG cargoes from the United States only in October and November.
